I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) proposed 
supplementary  grant;  and  (ii)  the  proposed  administration  of  a  supplementary  grant  to  be 
provided by the Asian Clean Energy Fund1 under the Clean Energy Partnership Facility, to the 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Public–Private Infrastructure Development Facility 
(PPIDF).2 
 
II.  THE APPROVED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
 
2.  On 2 October 2008, the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
approved  two  loans  (one  of  $82  million  from  ordinary  capital  resources  and  the  other  of 
SDR52,870,000 from special fund resources) to Bangladesh for the PPIDF Project. 
 
3.  The project is helping to address infrastructure deficiencies in Bangladesh, and thereby 
promote economic growth and poverty reduction, by providing long-term debt financing and 
catalyzing private sector participation through Infrastructure Development Company Limited 
(IDCOL). It is divided into three main components, with each one having different target groups 
and objectives.  
 
(i)  Component A uses $82 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to provide 
dollar financing to the government for relending to IDCOL to finance large private 
sector-sponsored infrastructure subprojects of at least $30 million.  
(ii)  Component B provides Asian Development Fund (ADF) funding of $50 million 
equivalent to the government for relending in local currency to IDCOL to finance 
small and medium-sized infrastructure subprojects primarily located in rural and 
semi-urban areas, especially in the energy sector.  
(iii)  Component  C  provides  ADF  funding  of  $33  million  equivalent  for  IDCOL’s 
ongoing renewable energy program. One of the main objectives of this program 
is  to  help  provide  the  rural  population  in  off-grid  areas  with  access  to 
environment-friendly electricity by financing renewable energy systems (RESs), 
such as solar home systems (SHSs), biomass and biogas installations, through a 
microfinance-based, direct sales program. 
 
B.  Status of Project Implementation 
 
4.  As of April 2011, there have been no disbursements under component A. However, a 
number of projects are expected to reach financial closure within the next few months. IDCOL is 
currently  reviewing  the  financing  of  3  independent  power  plants 3  recently  awarded  by 
Bangladesh Power Development Board. In addition, 12 projects totaling 2,295 megawatts (MW) 
are in the pipeline. 
 
                                                
1  Established by the Government of Japan. 
2  The revised design and monitoring framework is in the Appendix. 
3  Summit Group, the largest power conglomerate in Bangladesh, has recently been awarded the right to develop 3 
large independent power plants: (i) the 2 Bibiyana gas-fired combined cycle power plants of 341 MW each for 
phases 1 and 2, and (ii) the Meghnaghat 335 MW dual fuel-combined cycle power plant. In addition, the Ranhill-
STS-Consortium from Malaysia has won the bid to build the Bhola 225 MW gas-fired combined cycle power plant.

2   
5.  Under component B, ADB has made one disbursement of $5 million in April 2010 to 
IDCOL for providing a term loan facility of Tk350 million to an information technology company 
for the establishment and operation of a nationwide wireless broadband network. Another local 
currency  loan  of  Tk200  million  from  IDCOL  to  a  company  that  operates  a  nationwide 
telecommunication transmission network using fiber optic technology has been approved by 
IDCOL’s board and will soon be disbursed. IDCOL’s current project pipeline for component B 
consists of several small to medium-sized, primarily gas-fired power plants. In addition, IDCOL’s 
board has approved 3 projects that will set up solar photovoltaic module assembly facilities with 
a capacity ranging from 5 MW to 10 MW each. 
 
6.  Progress  in  implementing  component  C  to  finance  access  to  environment-friendly 
electricity in off-grid areas has been successful. As of April 2011, 97% or $32 million of the total 
available ADF funds of $33 million have been disbursed to finance 104,273 SHSs. It is expected 
that the unutilized amount will be disbursed in the next few months for further financing of SHSs.  
 
III.  IDCOL’S RENEWABLE ENERGY PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
7.  Lack of access to reliable electricity has been one of the most severe constraints to 
economic growth and improved livelihoods in Bangladesh. Although 75% of the population lives 
in rural areas, only about 30% of rural households have access to grid electricity. The current 
electrification rate is about 400,000 households a year and, at such a rate, it would take more 
than 40 years to reach all households. Against this backdrop, the power sector has been 
prioritized by the government to provide universal electricity access by 2020. 
 
8.  Given  the  slow  pace  of  grid  extension,  the  government  strategy  emphasizes  the 
promotion of off-grid renewable energy technologies in rural areas as a priority. Thus, off-grid 
electrification  based  on  RESs  is  the  only  readily  available  and  cost-effective  electricity 
applications for millions of people in areas without access to a conventional energy supply. 
Such applications are wide-ranging, including SHSs, biomass, micro-wind power systems in 
coastal areas, and mini-hydro projects in the mountainous regions. 
 
9.  Promotion of renewable energy is also preferred from the viewpoint of providing clean 
energy  technologies,  since  most  of  the  power  generation  in  Bangladesh  for  lighting  and 
pumping water for irrigation uses kerosene and diesel. About 75% of the population also relies 
on biomass, such as rice straw, dried leaves, jute sticks, cow dung, or wood, for cooking and 
heating. These sources of energy cause high CO  emissions and are an inefficient use of 
2
resources. Introduction of efficient renewable energy can thus have a positive impact on the 
environment by reducing CO  emissions and preventing deforestation. To accelerate the use of 
2
these energy applications, the government decided to mandate IDCOL with the financing of 
SHS installations and other renewable energy applications in off-grid areas. 
 
B.  Overview of IDCOL’s Renewable Energy Program 
 
10.  IDCOL’s renewable energy program provides refinancing, sets technical specifications 
for equipment, develops publicity materials, extends loans, installs the systems, monitors their 
performance, and provides maintenance support. In particular, IDCOL provides:

3 
(i)  loans at 6%–8% (per annum) to participating organizations,4 which then provide 
customers in rural areas with financing of up to 80% of the cost of an SHS5 with a 
capacity of 10–130 watts;6  
(ii)  loans to companies for biomass installations in rural or semi-urban areas, and 
financing for commercial and semi-commercial biogas plants or biogas-based 
electricity plants; and 
(iii)  loans and grants for solar irrigation pumps.  
 
11.  Funds used by IDCOL for refinancing stem exclusively from donor loans channeled 
through the government. IDCOL’s main responsibility is, therefore, to raise and channel funding 
in the form of loans to participating organizations and to monitor the overall performance of its 
renewable  energy  program.  Participating  organizations,  in  a  second  step,  will  then  select 
subproject  areas  and  potential  customers,  extend  loans,  install  the  systems,  monitor  their 
performance, and provide maintenance support.  
 
12.  In  addition  to  the  refinancing  arrangement,  donors  devised  a  grant  scheme7 to 
incentivize  IDCOL  and  its  participating  organizations  to  increase  the  affordability  of  these 
renewable energy applications to buyers in rural off-grid areas, where the poorer section of the 
population normally lives. The prices of SHSs depend not only on the institutional capacity of 
IDCOL and its participating organizations in operating cost-efficiently but also on world prices for 
the various system components that are subject to demand and supply. Thus, the grant scheme 
will shelter end-users from some of the price fluctuations as well as accelerate use of the 
program.   
 
C.  Status of IDCOL’s Solar Energy Program 
 
13.  Since IDCOL first started to finance SHSs in collaboration with the World Bank in 2002, 
the initial target of financing 50,000 SHSs was achieved in August 2005, 3 years ahead of the 
target  date  and  $2  million  below  estimated  costs.  In  view  of  this  successful  program 
implementation, IDCOL raised its target to finance 1,000,000 SHSs by 2012. As of October 
2010, a total of 702,574 SHSs have been installed and the current installation rate is roughly 
                                                
4  IDCOL’s renewable energy program is innovative because it is implemented through participating organizations, 
which  are  nongovernment  organizations,  microfinance  institutions,  and  private  entities.  These  participating 
organizations  select  project  areas  and  potential  customers,  extend  loans,  install  the  systems,  and  provide 
maintenance support. Through this scheme, IDCOL can take advantage of participating organizations’ grassroots 
networks, which are vital for introducing efficient technology to underdeveloped rural areas and encouraging 
community participation. 
5  SHSs are small photovoltaic systems with a peak capacity of between 10 watts and 130 watts and comprise a 
solar panel, battery, charge controller, wires, and loads. The estimated technical lifetime of a solar panel for a SHS 
is about 20 years, 5–7 years for a battery, and 3 years for a charge controller. Maintenance and after-sales service 
are provided free of charge within the first 3 years of purchase. During this time, the systems are regularly checked 
by participating organization staff while collecting the monthly installments. After the 3-year payback period, 
maintenance is provided by the participating organizations for a minimal monthly fee. As SHS users are owners of 
their systems, motivation to keep the system running will be high. As there are no further monthly installments after 
the payback period, the payment of a small monthly service fee as well as the replacement of the battery every 5 
years will not be a major financial obstacle. 
6  SHS are used mainly by low- and middle-class households, and micro- and small enterprises in off-grid rural 
locations to operate light bulbs, small electrical appliances like mobile chargers, and black and white television 
sets. Households, and micro- and small enterprises buy SHSs either by cash or credit, but they are required to pay 
a minimum 10% of the cost as a down payment. The price of a typical 50-watt SHS is about $400. 
7  The grant scheme consists of (i) a buy-down grant to reduce the consumer price of the SHS, (ii) a grant to IDCOL 
for management and monitoring of the use of refinancing loans and grant components, and (iii) an institutional 
development fund available to the participating organizations to widen their outreach capacities in rural areas.

4   
30,000 SHSs per month. At this pace, it is expected that the target will be achieved by August 
2011. Therefore, IDCOL has recently revised its target to 2.5 million SHSs by 2014. 
 
14.  As  of  September  2010,  additional  funding  from  the World  Bank  and  other  donors, 
including ADB and the Islamic Development Bank, to IDCOL’s solar energy program amounted 
to approximately $170 million. In addition, the Global Environment Facility, Global Partnership 
on Output-Based Aid, and German development cooperation through GIZ and KfW pledged 
grants worth $45.5 million.  
 
D.  Status of IDCOL’s Financing of Other Renewable Energy Applications 
 
15.  Beyond the financing of SHSs, IDCOL finances other renewable energy applications 
such as biogas, biomass, solar, and wind energy installations. IDCOL finances up to 80% of 
total costs of renewable energy subprojects by providing a combination of debt and grant 
financing. A financial analysis for each subproject determines the necessary grant and loan 
elements, with grant financing constituting a maximum of 50% of total subproject costs for solar 
mini-grid projects and 40% for solar irrigation projects. With regard to biomass and biogas-
based power plants, one 250 kilowatt (kW) project is already in operation, while one biomass-
based power plant with a capacity of 400 kW and one biogas-based power plant of 50 kW are 
under construction. One additional 350 kW biogas-based power plant has been approved by 
IDCOL’s board and will start construction soon. In addition, an 11.2 kW solar irrigation pump is 
in operation and an 8.4 kW solar irrigation pump will be constructed shortly. Finally, IDCOL has 
given preliminary approval for the financing of 17 solar irrigation pump projects. 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY GRANTS 
 
A.  Proposed Changes 
 
16.  The proposed changes relate to the grant funding for component C of the project, which 
finances RESs. ADB originally intended to apply for grant financing from the Asian Clean 
Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility and from the Climate 
Change Fund in parallel with the processing of the project. However, the application process for 
funding from these 2 sources was not completed by the time the project was approved by ADB’s 
Board  on  2 October  2008.  As  a  consequence, the grant financing  is  being  processed  as 
supplementary grants for the project. The proposed allocation of $3.3 million to the project will 
be funded as follows: 
 
(i)  Grant cofinancing equivalent to $2,000,000 will be provided by the Asian Clean 
Energy  Fund8 under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility,  and 
administered by ADB.  
(ii)  A grant of $1,300,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources will be provided by 
the Climate Change Fund (CCF).9  
 
17.  The total grant amounts will be divided into two parts to pursue distinct objectives, apply 
specific lending modalities, and target different beneficiary groups. Part 1 will use the $2 million 
allocation  under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility  to  enable  participating 
organizations (through IDCOL) to provide buy-down grants and institutional development grants 
for individual SHSs of at least 10 watts. The buy-down grant for each SHS will be $2510 and will

organizations  by  IDCOL  after  sufficient  verification  in  accordance  with  the  procedures 
established under component C of the project. This will enable at least 80,000 low- and middle-

While loan financing under component C of the project is largely exhausted, the proposed

18.  Under part 2, IDCOL will use $580,000 of the allocation of $1.3 million under the CCF to 
offer grants under its direct financing activities to some of its medium-scale subprojects using 
renewable energy applications such as biomass, biogas, and wind energy installations in rural 
areas with no access to grid electricity. Up to 50% of the total cost of an individual subproject 
can  be  financed  with  a  grant  from  part  2.  As  was  the  case  with  the  implementation 
arrangements  under  component  B  of  the  project,  the  first  3  subprojects  to  receive  grant 
financing under part 2 will be submitted to ADB for review and approval prior to disbursement by 
IDCOL, unless otherwise agreed between ADB and IDCOL. 
 
19.  The remaining amount under the CCF will be provided to IDCOL to pay for the following 
expenses related to the administration and monitoring of its renewable energy program under 
part 1:  
 
(i)  $357,000  as  the  program  support  administration  cost  of  IDCOL  for  the

based on an administration cost of $4.46 per SHS11 installed.12 
(ii)  $233,000 as an institutional development fund for the training of participating 
organization staff and their customers to widen their outreach capacities in rural 
areas. Because of the expanding network of supply and maintenance outlets, 
maintenance,  services,  and  spare  parts  are  available  within  a  reasonable 
distance from the SHS customers. Currently, the typical radius for each outlet is 
around 10 kilometers. 
(iii)  $30,000 for technical inspections.13 
(iv)  $60,000 for annual technical audits14 to be carried out by an audit firm for 2 
consecutive years. 
(v)  $40,000 for appointing independent engineers15 to conduct feasibility studies, 
and appraise and monitor renewable energy projects.

B.  Rationale for Supplementary Grants 
 
21.  The main rationale for the proposed supplementary grants is to increase the financing 
available to the rural poor for the purchase of an SHS which is in line with the provision of grant 
money already done by other donors. The funds will subsidize SHSs and other renewable 
energy applications in order to make them more affordable to end-users, thereby guaranteeing 
increased  SHS  installation  rates  and  the  successful  implementation  of  alternative  energy 
generation  in  off-grid  areas.  This  will  assist  the  government  in  implementing  its  vision  of 
universal electricity access by 2020.  
 
22.  The  additional  activities  under  component  C  are  consistent  with  (i)  ADB’s  country 
strategy and program update 2006–2010 for Bangladesh,16 which highlights rural electrification 
as one of the key development challenges; (ii) the original development objectives; and (iii) the 
project’s  impact,  outcomes,  and  development  effectiveness  as  well  as  the  design  and 
monitoring framework in the Appendix. Furthermore, the renewable energy program component 
demonstrates  satisfactory  implementation  and  is  likely  to  achieve  the  stated  development 
objectives as highlighted in sections III C and III D on the status of IDCOL’s renewable energy 
programs. 
 
C.  Impact on the Project 
 
23.  The supplementary grants will (i) provide under part 1 further support for this highly 
successful  intervention  in  the  absence  of  sufficient  grant  funding  sources  to  achieve  the 
targeted 2.5 million SHSs by 2014; (ii) promote clean energy technologies, which will lead to a 
reduction of greenhouse gas emissions; and (iii) contribute to poverty reduction and sustainable 
development. 
 
                                                
16 ADB. 2005, Bangladesh: Country Strategy and Program Update, 2006–2010. Manila.

7 
24.  With respect to the provision of grants for the purchase of SHSs under part 1, the 
proposed changes will improve the access of low-income households to clean energy. The 
extreme  poor  will  benefit  mostly  since  they  are  otherwise  deprived  of  access  to  reliable 
electricity. In the long term, a self-sustaining market for SHSs will be created in Bangladesh, 
which will: 
 
(i)  replace fossil fuel (kerosene) lamps through modern electricity from renewable 
sources;  
(ii)  provide better lighting for school children as they study in the evening;  
(iii)  provide more security for household members, especially women and children;  
(iv)  help save money that is being spent on kerosene or candles; 
(v)  help save time needed for purchasing kerosene; and 
(vi)  improve indoor air quality and health by avoiding the burning of kerosene. 
 
25.  IDCOL’s high installation rates of SHSs and other renewable energy applications will 
help contribute to reduced carbon emissions. IDCOL estimates that each SHS saves at least 
$61.8 worth of kerosene each year, and reduces 345 kilograms of CO  emission annually as a 
2
result. Therefore, the 80,000 new SHSs to be installed through the proposed changes will bring 
a reduction of about 27,600 tons of CO  emissions a year. IDCOL is currently assessing the 
2
carbon emission reductions achieved by RESs other than SHSs. 
 
26.  The proposed supplementary grants will facilitate additional financing of SHSs by IDCOL 
through the provision of 80,000 grants, thereby increasing the number of SHSs to be financed 
under the project from the current 104,273 SHSs to at least 180,000 SHSs. As a result, IDCOL 
is more likely to meet its objective of financing 2.5 million SHSs by 2014.  
 
27.  Currently, the overall funding available to IDCOL is sufficient to provide financing for 
772,321 SHSs. In light of the current installation rates, existing funding is expected to be 
depleted in the second quarter of 2011 and the available ADB financing under component C is 
equally expected to be fully utilized by 2011. More specifically on loan financing, IDCOL faces a 
funding gap of roughly $408 million for the financing of approximately 1,825,000 SHSs to reach 
its goal of financing 2.5 million SHSs by 2014.  
 
28.  Without ADB’s proposed grant financing under part 1, part of IDCOL’s SHS program 
may be financed without the grant element, which could cause the price of an SHS to become 
unaffordable to a large section of society, thereby leading to declining demand from customers. 
In addition, customers would have to bear administration support costs, given that these are 
generally  covered  by  grant  funding.  According  to  IDCOL’s  estimates,  this  could  lead  to 
significantly  lower  installation  rates  and  a  customer  base  that  will  consist  primarily  of  the 
relatively better-off residents in rural and urban areas. In this scenario, IDCOL may miss its 
target of installing 2.5 million SHSs by 2014. Thus, the proposed supplementary funding will 
help maintain the current high installation rate and assist IDCOL in achieving its target, while 
retaining a more inclusive customer base for SHS installations. 
 
29.  IDCOL has in its pipeline projects for other renewable energy applications, but is also 
short of funding for these projects. ADB has allocated about $3 million under component C and 
the International Development Agency has pledged loan financing of $6 million, while the Global 
Environment  Facility,  Global  Partnership  on  Output-Based  Aid,  and  German  development 
cooperation through KfW have contributed a total of $3.1 million in grant funding. Assuming the 
proposed ADB grant financing is approved under part 2, IDCOL estimates that its shortfall for 
grant financing will still be about $9.6 million and for loan financing, it will be $12 million.

8   
D.  Environmental and Social Safeguards 
 
30.  Environmental safeguards. The proposed project is classified as category FI. As part 
of ADB’s earlier assistance under the original loan, IDCOL has established an environmental 
and social safeguards framework that will be updated to reflect the changes in connection with 
this additional grant funding and ongoing ADB-financed capacity building efforts for the benefit 
of IDCOL’s Environmental and Social Safeguards Management Unit. Given the small size and 
retail character of an SHS installation, no adverse environmental impacts are expected through 
these supplementary grants. The only potential negative environmental impact of the SHS 
dissemination program could originate from battery-related waste problems. To limit negative 
effects on the natural environment, IDCOL requires all participating organizations to ensure that, 
when batteries reach the end of their lifetime (typically 5–7 years), they are  collected from rural 
customers and returned to the battery manufacturer for recycling purposes. To assure complete 
collection of old batteries, most participating organizations offer small amounts of money for the 
return of used batteries to their respective offices. IDCOL requires all battery manufacturers to 
have  International  Organization  for  Standardization  (ISO)  14001  certified  battery  recycling 
facilities. All battery manufacturers are in the process of obtaining ISO 14001 certificates in 
2011. 
 
31.  Social safeguards. The proposed supplementary grants are classified as category C. 
No involuntary resettlement or any impact on indigenous peoples is expected as a result of this 
financing. The environmental and social safeguards framework under the original loan will 
remain in place with respect to any social safeguard concerns resulting from this additional 
grant funding. 
 
E.  Revised Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
32.  The cost estimates for the installation of SHSs have not changed and remain dependent 
on market prices and the institutional capacity of IDCOL and participating organizations to 
reduce their operational costs.  
 
33.  The original financing plan will be marginally changed since the proposed supplementary 
grants  will  only  impact component  C  of  PPIDF  which  will  provide  financing for renewable 
subprojects. The project will complement the grant funding sources available to IDCOL for its 
renewable energy program and will, therefore, have a positive effect on component C. The 
revised financing plan is provided in Table 2.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
34.  Implementation arrangements for the project under the proposed supplementary grants, 
including project management; application of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date);  disbursement  arrangements;  accounting,  auditing,  and  reporting;  and  project  review 
remain the same as those for the original loan. In addition, two imprest accounts will be opened 
to administer the disbursements of the Asian Clean Energy Fund and CCF grants. 
 
G.  Procurement 
35.  For the provision of buy-down grants of $25 to end-users for the purchase of individual 
SHSs  and  for  the  provision  of  grants  by  IDCOL  to  subprojects  using  renewable  energy 
applications such as biomass, biogas, and wind, IDCOL will require participating organizations 
to procure goods and works in compliance with established commercial practices that are 
acceptable to ADB. IDCOL and the participating organizations will (i) procure goods and works 
by adopting international competitive bidding procedures for the purchase of large single items 
or for bulk purchasing in cases where large quantities of like goods can be grouped together; 
and (ii) ensure that goods and works are purchased at a reasonable price, with account being 
taken also of other relevant factors such as time of delivery, efficiency and reliability of the 
goods, and their suitability for the activities of the participating organizations.  
 
V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
36.  The project benefits, impacts, assumptions, and risks remain the same as those stated 
in the original report and recommendation of the President.17 Project implementation period will 
not be extended.  
VI.  ASSURANCES 
 
37.  Assurances provided by the government in the original loans shall be applied to the 
extent they are applicable to the proposed project.  
 
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed supplementary grants would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
 
(i)  the grant not exceeding $1,300,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh from 
ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  for  the  Public–Private  Infrastructure 
Development Facility; and 
 
(ii)  the administration by ADB of a grant not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Public–Private  Infrastructure 
Development Facility to be provided by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the 
Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility.
